text:
A client of mine has a sister company who has just migrated their website to a new CMS. I don't know the ins and outs of how they did it but all their content has dived from first/second page of Google to nowhere to be seen.

Has anybody got any first-hand experience of this/read a good case study on recovery from something like this?

elements.text:
A client of mine has a sister company who has just migrated their website to a new CMS. I don't know the ins and outs of how they did it but all their content has dived from first/second page of Google to nowhere to be seen.

Has anybody got any first-hand experience of this/read a good case study on recovery from something like this?

text:
Managing technical SEO for migrations isn't my forte, but when I've seen clients faceplant migrations like this, there are some easy culprits to check for:
1. New CMS isn't indexing the site or those particular pieces of content.
2. Content is unpublished/not public in the new CMS
3. New CMS uses a different URL scheme, so all of the posts have different URLs with no redirects from the old ones.

elements.text: Managing technical SEO for migrations isn't my forte, but when I've seen clients faceplant migrations like this, there are some easy culprits to check for:
New CMS isn't indexing the site or those particular pieces of content.
Content is unpublished/not public in the new CMS
New CMS uses a different URL scheme, so all of the posts have different URLs with no redirects from the old ones.

text:
:point_up_2: I'd start with those 3 things Erik pointed out. Checkout their Google Search Console to see if URLs are being indexed. Verify any redirects, and submit a new sitemap to Google as well.

<https://www.semrush.com/blog/cms-migration-guide/>

attachments.title: CMS Migration Guide: A Checklist
attachments.text: Want to migrate your site from one CMS to another? Find out all the steps you should take to make sure the transition is smooth and your website remains in tact.
attachments.fallback: Semrush Blog: CMS Migration Guide: A Checklist

elements.text: I'd start with those 3 things Erik pointed out. Checkout their Google Search Console to see if URLs are being indexed. Verify any redirects, and submit a new sitemap to Google as well.

text: I’m looking for content agency recommendations. Who can create well-done SEO-focused blog content for a B2B business but do it in more of an engaging B2C style? Really focused on the creation side of things, we have the SEO strategy and targets defined.

elements.text: I’m looking for content agency recommendations. Who can create well-done SEO-focused blog content for a B2B business but do it in more of an engaging B2C style? Really focused on the creation side of things, we have the SEO strategy and targets defined.

attachments.text: We're a content creation and SEO agency. Trusted by Fortune 500 companies and Y Combinator startups, we help you get more customers through SEO-focused content marketing.

attachments.title: Content Creators Agency | White Glove SEO Copy, Social, & Email
attachments.text: Content Creators Agency, LLC is an agency specializing in content for SEO articles, organic social media growth, and email newsletter services.
attachments.fallback: Content Creators Agency: Content Creators Agency | White Glove SEO Copy, Social, & Email

text:
In my experience, b2b businesses aren't that interested in syndicating already-published content unless you're already quite famous / have a large audience.

Generally, folks become established writers on publications (eg. Hackernoon) and then syndicate some of their original content there (or vice versa).

The most effect b2b content syndication simply turns into `guest posting` where you give them your entire original content piece.

elements.text:

guest posting
where you give them your entire original content piece.

text: I'd actually recommend against any type of bigger agency based on my 12+ yrs working with content creators (agencies, freelancers, boutiques, etc), and instead find a high quality freelancer(s) or small boutique. Personally I've had very positive experiences with: <https://www.kaleighmoore.com/>, <https://storiesby.us/> & <https://www.kieraabbamonte.com/>

elements.text: I'd actually recommend against any type of bigger agency based on my 12+ yrs working with content creators (agencies, freelancers, boutiques, etc), and instead find a high quality freelancer(s) or small boutique. Personally I've had very positive experiences with:

text:
I just went through this with my team and something the migration tools can miss are three easy SEO fixes. For context, we migrated from WordPress to Craft CMS and used Craft's migration services to move the bulk of the content. The fixes we made were:
• SEO Title
• Meta description
• Ft/SEO image alt text
We also noticed a lot of redirects made in WP didn't carry over to Craft, which meant broken URLs. We used SEMrush and the Retour plugin for Craft to find the broken URLs and correct the redirects for them. We made the decision to do this manually to improve them, but when we first imported, a lot of these were either missing or wrong. Checking them is definitely a good place start

elements.text: I just went through this with my team and something the migration tools can miss are three easy SEO fixes. For context, we migrated from WordPress to Craft CMS and used Craft's migration services to move the bulk of the content. The fixes we made were:
SEO Title
Meta description
Ft/SEO image alt text

We also noticed a lot of redirects made in WP didn't carry over to Craft, which meant broken URLs. We used SEMrush and the Retour plugin for Craft to find the broken URLs and correct the redirects for them. We made the decision to do this manually to improve them, but when we first imported, a lot of these were either missing or wrong. Checking them is definitely a good place start

text:
Hey everyone, what’s your thoughts on link sculpting? I’m reviewing a clients site and making plans to beef up their internal linking so that more authority can pass to money pages. 

I’ve heard people get real technical about the number of links on the page. As in, making some internal links (like to privacy page) no-follow. 

(Sounds kinda crazy. But crazy also has a way of not sounding crazy. Am I right? :man-shrugging::laughing:)

Does anyone here have some advice/article on the best tactics to “focus” that link juice?

elements.text:
